title: Cannot publish R package from GitHub because of incorrect License ID (GPL-3 or later)
body:
I'm on Firefox on Arch Linux.

## Describe the bug
I'm trying to link my github repo https://github.com/japhir/snvecR to generate a Zenodo publication with a DOI for a new R package.
I've done this many times before and it has always worked.

However, now I get the following error:
```
{
    "errors": "The license ID you have selected is not present in our system. For the available licenses please check in the following URL https://developers.zenodo.org/#licenses"
}
```

From https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo/issues/1933 I can see that you use the spdx list of license names.
From https://spdx.org/licenses/ I can see that since version 3.0 of this database, it expects to get `GPL-3.0-or-later`. 
Looking at the payload of my failed submission, it looks like Github has given it a `"spdx_id": "GPL-3.0", `, which is marked as deprecated.

How can I customize this value so that the github release triggers a zenodo archive correctly?

title: Can't find latest version of record via API
body:
Browser & OS: Chrome 103, MacOS Monterey

## Describe the bug
REST API requests sometimes do not return the latest version of a deposit on Zenodo Sandbox. I find this happening specifically for https://sandbox.zenodo.org/record/1089608, which (currently) has 5 versions, but only the first 4 show up via an API search. Note that when a new version is created for this deposit, the previous version becomes visible to an API request. So the issue is specifically with the latest version. I also do not get this issue with other deposits (e.g., https://sandbox.zenodo.org/record/1057227), for which the API request returns the same number of versions I can see via the browser.

## Steps to Reproduce
Running the following python code

```python
import requests


def print_version_dois(conceptdoi):
    r = requests.get(
        f"https://sandbox.zenodo.org/api/records",
        params={
            "q": f'conceptdoi:"{conceptdoi}"',
            "all_versions": 1,
        },
    )
    records = r.json().get("hits", {}).get("hits", [])

    print(f"{len(records)} versions found for {conceptdoi}:")
    for record in records:
        print(f"    10.5072/zenodo.{record['id']}")


print_version_dois("10.5072/zenodo.1089608")
```
currently prints
```text
4 versions found for 10.5072/zenodo.1089608:
    10.5072/zenodo.1089609
    10.5072/zenodo.1089610
    10.5072/zenodo.1089722
    10.5072/zenodo.1089737
```
However, as you can see in the screenshot below, there are 5 versions of the deposit. The most recent one (1090055) is missing.

## Expected behavior
The API search should return all the versions associated with a given concept DOI.

## Screenshots (if applicable)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9323819/182398356-94f3f70c-0324-4133-ad48-28d612f47bf7.png)

## Additional context
There's a `last_child` element in the JSON response of the GET request that actually points to the (correct) last version, so in principle I can locate it.

Thanks in advance for looking into this!

title: GET records requests on Zenodo API (as anonymous) give Internal Server Errors
body:
Related to https://github.com/eblondel/zen4R/issues/84

## Describe the bug
Some user reported that interrogating the Zenodo API as anonymous user, to get published records (based on their DOI or concept DOI) leads to _Internal Server Errors_. This is done using the R [zen4R](https://github.com/eblondel/zen4R). I've added a user agent as request header. Although we get some successful requests, we get randomly Internal server errors, and adding the User-Agent didn't fix systematically the errors.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Install R
2. Install R packages:

```R
install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("eblondel/zen4R")
```
3. Execute the following R code

```R
library(zen4R)
zenodo <- ZenodoManager$new(logger = "INFO")
rec <- zenodo$getRecordByDOI("10.5281/zenodo.3378733")
```
The same test is configured as part of zen4R Github CI action running on Ubuntu latest, and both R release and devel. Tests do not pass systematically, and randomly we get _Internal Server Errors_, which let me think it is independent from the User-Agent, and may have different reasons (limits in number of requests controlled by IP address?)

## Expected behavior

- No Internal server error anymore

## Additional notes

I  would also like to know if there is some place where Zenodo server changes are reported, like the need of User-Agent etc; which would help maintain in better way zen4R and proceed with changes in timely manner.

Thanks in advance!
Emmanuel

title: access-requests: deleted record with access requests cause a 500 at shared links settings page
body:
When rendering the Shared links settings page, each [request's recid is resolved](https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo-accessrequests/blob/ce2cf3f1425d02ba4f3ad3202cfca43a1892558a/zenodo_accessrequests/templates/zenodo_accessrequests/settings/index.html#L39) without handling cases where the record/recid might be deleted. There are two possible solutions:

- (Preferred solution) Change the [record deletion logic](https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo/blob/f4ec79bc75fec2dd18cf4255dc5e1c4c1c8f1084/zenodo/modules/deposit/utils.py#L112) to also clean-up after access requests (i.e. `AccessRequest.query.filter_by(recid=int(recid.pid_value)).delete()`)
  - This also requires fixing the data in production by going through all the `AccessRequest` table and deleting all of them that include a deleted `recid`. 
- Filter access requests in the view/template of the settings page to show only existing records

title: access-requests: accepted/declined requests give a 404 page
body:
Access requests that have been accepted/declined [give back a 404 page](https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo-accessrequests/blob/ce2cf3f1425d02ba4f3ad3202cfca43a1892558a/zenodo_accessrequests/views/settings.py#L137) (e.g. if the user clicks the link shipped via email). We should either:

- Display a "access request already accepted/rejected" page
- ~~Create a proper item page for access requests (that are not just pending)~~

On another note, in general, access requests responses for [email confirmation](https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo-accessrequests/blob/ce2cf3f1425d02ba4f3ad3202cfca43a1892558a/zenodo_accessrequests/views/requests.py#L159), etc. should be revisited, since the content of the responses (if any) does not help the user understand what they should do/expect or on whose hands it is to follow-up (i.e. record owner vs. requester).

title: oai-pmh: ListSets fails with 500 code
body:
Running the following snippet to harvest the `ListSets` OAI-PMH verb fails with a 500

```python
In [1]: import sickle
In [2]: client = sickle.Sickle('https://zenodo.org/oai2d')
In [4]: all_sets = list(client.ListSets())
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
HTTPError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)

...

HTTPError: 500 Server Error: INTERNAL SERVER ERROR for url: https://zenodo.org/oai2d?verb=ListSets&resumptionToken=eyJzZWVkIjowLjUyNzg1MzU0Nzg5NjEyNiwicGFnZSI6NDcsImt3YXJncyI6e319.YccFqQ._ZEdN8jpyubCYRUcuMypfm28WQU
```

---

Had a further look into it and apparently, it's an invalid XML characters issue:

```python
[2021-12-29 12:01:18,831] ERROR in app: Exception on /oai2d [GET]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 2317, in wsgi_app
    response = self.full_dispatch_request()
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1840, in full_dispatch_request
    rv = self.handle_user_exception(e)
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1743, in handle_user_exception
    reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1838, in full_dispatch_request
    rv = self.dispatch_request()
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1824, in dispatch_request
    return self.view_functions[rule.endpoint](**req.view_args)
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/webargs/core.py", line 452, in wrapper
    return func(*new_args, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/invenio_oaiserver/views/server.py", line 84, in response
    e_tree = getattr(xml, args['verb'].lower())(**args)
  File "/opt/zenodo/lib/python2.7/site-packages/invenio_oaiserver/response.py", line 209, in listsets
    e_description.text = oai_set.description
  File "src/lxml/etree.pyx", line 1024, in lxml.etree._Element.text.__set__
  File "src/lxml/apihelpers.pxi", line 747, in lxml.etree._setNodeText
  File "src/lxml/apihelpers.pxi", line 735, in lxml.etree._createTextNode
  File "src/lxml/apihelpers.pxi", line 1540, in lxml.etree._utf8
ValueError: All strings must be XML compatible: Unicode or ASCII, no NULL bytes or control characters
```

So some community has a description that includes "NULL bytes or control characters".

title: support: names should be allowed to contain commas
body:
We have a rule in the support form that doesn't allow the "name" field to contain commas. Maybe there was some legacy reason for this rule (e.g. email sending failing, since we build a `Smith, John <john.smith@mail.com>` string), but in any case, this doesn't make much sense, so we should look into this and remove the validation to support names with commas (which e.g. is a norm for user profile names).

To replicate the issue:

1. Open the support form
2. Type a name that contains a comma (e.g. "Smith, John")
3. See error about names containing commas

title: record-ui: concept DOI wrongly displayed/generated in "Cite all versions" box
body:
To render the concept DOI (and link) in the record landing page, we're just "prefixing" the `conceptrecid` with our official DOI prefix. This causes issues in Sandbox records which now display links to Concept DOIs that actually exist from production (see [example](https://sandbox.zenodo.org/record/886789)).

Using the existing `record.conceptdoi` value to generate the displayed/linked values should be enough to solve the issue:
https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo/blob/1921f2f6063a002d77cd3d92d31ee994c6f4d4b6/zenodo/modules/records/templates/zenodo_records/box/versions.html#L38

title: ISBN not valid with isbnid
body:
## Describe the bug
When trying to add a new related identifier (in this case an ISBN) the library does not consider it "Valid".

![unknown](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/79139616/134365291-ce44d3c8-111f-435e-b706-61868c469715.png)

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a deposit
2. Go to the "Related identifiers" section and try to add an IBSN such as ``978-65-87773-12-4``

## Solution
Currently we are using the library https://github.com/inspirehep/isbnid and this should be replaced with https://github.com/xlcnd/isbnlib .

title: global: performance issues for records with many versions
body:
Records that have many versions (e.g. more than 100), have issues when e.g. users try to change on any of the versions some metadata and publish, to the point where the server responds with a `504 Gateway Timeout` (since the backend operations take too long). 

The publish process should be reviewed to understand why its cost is related to the number of versions... It could be that the API cycles through all versions to check something, or synchronously indexes all the record versions at once, etc

title: search: *records-files* mappings shouldn't be created at all
body: When running `zenodo index init` at the moment, the `records-records-files-v1.0.0` mapping/index is created and is included in the `records` alias. Since nothing is actually ever indexed there, when results are served from the index (because queries point to the `/records` alias) various errors show up (most commonly a sort is attempted on the `_created` field which is not defined in the mapping). The solution is to remove the `records/records-files-v1.0.0.json` mapping.

title: deposit: empty "_deposit.owners" and missing "_deposit.pid" for published deposits
body:
Some GitHub-originated deposits have  `_deposit.owners: []` and are missing the `pid` key even though they are published. This is a problem since users are not able to access the deposit (because of permissions) or delete/discard the deposit to correct the situation... The solution (from an admin POV) is to add the missing values correctly and then call `.discard()` on the deposit.

The most probable reason for that is that the deposit never goes through [this part](https://github.com/inveniosoftware/invenio-deposit/blob/f243ea1d01ab0a3bc92ade3262d1abdd2bc32447/invenio_deposit/api.py#L238-L244) of the creation process since there is no `current_user` during a GitHub release... There are deposits even from 2017-06, so this is related to introducing versioning probably.  

Another reason might be the non-`with` use of `db.session.begin_nested()` [here](https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo/blob/81ff5429c823b07c68d71710cae346ba7a150a13/zenodo/modules/github/api.py#L87).

Finding such records is possible via this ES query:

```python
from invenio_search.api import RecordsSearch

query = RecordsSearch(index='deposits').filter('missing', field='_deposit.owners')
for r in query.scan():
    print(r._deposit.id)
```

**Update:** to fix these broken deposit do the following:

```python
from zenodo.modules.deposit.resolvers import deposit_resolver
from invenio_db import db

depid, deposit = deposit_resolver.resolve(123456)
deposit['_deposit']['owners'] = [<correct owner>]
deposit['_deposit']['pid'] = {'type': 'recid', 'value': str(deposit['recid'])}
deposit.commit()
db.session.commit()
deposit.discard()
db.session.commit()
```

title: stats: bug with version stats aggregation
body:
Because the target aggregation indices are shared between `recid`s and `conceptrecid`s, bookmarks are shared as well. This causes aggregations on the record level to be computed but not on the version level. 

For more details, see https://github.com/inveniosoftware/invenio-stats/issues/65

title: previewer: zip files crash the web application
body:
Very large or malformed/non-standard zip files might cause an `std::bad_malloc` error when the previewer attempts to parse their header to produce the directory tree. The reason this happens also has to do with the underlying XRootD bindings probably, since if one attempts to do the same in the local filesystem, everything seems to work fine. 

The solution is probably to enforce a size limit directly to the previewer, which is checked beforehand instead of attempting the preview.

Example record/file: https://zenodo.org/record/1299599

Steps to reproduce in a shell:

```python
from zipfile import ZipFile
from invenio_files_rest.models import FileInstance

# With XRootD...
fi = FileInstance.query.get('c686ed52-f304-442b-91e9-e4fed713514b')
with fi.storage().open() as fp:
    zf = ZipFile(fp)
    # zf = ZipFile(fp, allowZip64=True)  # this doesn't change anything...
    # ...shell crashes with the following message:
    # terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::bad_alloc'
    #   what():  std::bad_alloc

# Locally...
with open('1.0.0.zip', 'rb') as fp:
    zf = ZipFile(fp)
    print(len(zf.filelist))
    # 20024
```

As a counter-example, the following files, although larger than 2Gb, just raise an exception: https://zenodo.org/record/1298604

title: records: datacite update task redis key expiration
body:
When doing `current_cache.set` if the `expire=-1` argument is not passed, the TTL of the key is reset to the default 300 seconds :unamused: 

Basically, we should check all the places where [`current_cache.set` is called](https://github.com/zenodo/zenodo/blob/d47667e477d4678438c429b14fa3992b0ddf724c/zenodo/modules/records/tasks.py#L117), and use the `expire=-1` parameter, so that the task is not cancelled after 5min.

title: api: Internal Server Error when updating metadata if field is missing
body:
When using [the API](http://developers.zenodo.org/#update) to update the metadata for a previously published deposition, it is very easy to leave out some of the keys — like `doi`, for example.  When this is done, and the user tries to save or publish the updated version, the server returns a 500 error through the API.  If the user then tries to save or publish the updated version via the website, the same 500 error appears.  This case is even worse, because the web interface doesn't mark the DOI as a required field, so it is completely mystifying that the deposition can neither be saved nor published.

It would be much better if the error message could explain why the error is happening.  Or perhaps this could be avoided entirely when the metadata is updated.  In python, this would work by taking the required subset of the current metadata as a dictionary, and then updating that dictionary with the user's input dictionary.  If any of the required entries are changed by the user, they would be updated correctly, but the updated dictionary would retain any other required entries unchanged, while also allowing non-required entries to be added or altered.

title: github: refresh user's repository list in a periodic task
body:
Unused GitHub tokens become invalid after a year, because the Zenodo application on GitHub side is removed (by GitHub). This requires re-authentication for all users which haven't synced their repositories in a while. To prevent this in the future, we should sync user's repositories (which resets expiration date of the token).

The task should go through all remote accounts which haven't been synched in more than several months (configurable). The timestamp can be read from the GitHub Remote Account "extra_data" JSON field.

title: Deposit-UI: clearing openaire subtype on community removal
body: Currently the subtype is cleared on community removal (any community). Ideally this should only happen if the remaining communities no longer support the selected type (only).

title: support-form: better handling of file upload UX
body:
The following scenario has become pretty common:

1. User uploads file in support form and submits
2. Form has some validation error (invalid email address, short description, etc)
3. Page is rendered to display field errors, but the file upload field is lost (no file included in form)
4. User forgets, or is not aware of the missing the file, and submits the form without the file

Possible solutions (in order of preference):

- Validate the form on the client side
- Include some extra info to the template when rendering the validation error in case the user had included a file

title: serializers: BibTex escape special characters
body:
Current BibTex export is not escaping special characters such as ampersands ("&"), causing trouble in applications that use LaTeX. Example record: https://zenodo.org/record/345946/export/hx.

A list/sepcification of these special characters should be found and escaped during serialization using backslashes (eg. `{ Some subject \& another subject }` ). More information can be found in [this SO thread](http://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/7198/how-to-escape-the-ampersand-character-in-bibtex).

title: deposit: REST API is accepting metadata format, which is later incorrectly rendered on UI.

REST API allows for passing old-style grant information like:

```
"grants": [{'id': "123456"}]

title: deposit: removing DOI when editing a published record shouldn't be possible
body:
Currently editing a published record and completely removing/clearing the DOI field in the deposit form, is a "Save"-able state, from which though the user cannot recover (clicking "Pre-reserve DOI", or filling in the DOI manually and saving results to an "internal server error").

In order to tackle this issue, two steps are required:
- [x] Proper validation of the submitted deposit data with regard to the fact that it's a deposit of an already published record.
- [ ] Disabling the DOI field in deposit form when the published record uses a Zenodo DOI.

title: github: badges should contain no caching headers
body:
1. Create a GitHub release, insert the badge in README
1. Create another release
1. **Badge still renders the old image, although it properly redirects to the new release**
1. Refreshing browser cache does not work (nor does changing the browser), since the images are hosted (and cached) on GitHub side once the badge is added.

This is a Travis badge SVG response headers:
```
> $ curl https://travis-ci.org/zenodo/zenodo.svg\?branch\=master -L -I                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
Server: Cowboy
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2016 13:11:35 GMT
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type: text/html;charset=utf-8
Location: https://api.travis-ci.org/zenodo/zenodo.svg?branch=master
X-Xss-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN
Content-Length: 0
Via: 1.1 vegur

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Connection: keep-alive
Server: nginx
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2016 13:11:36 GMT
Content-Type: image/svg+xml
Content-Length: 726
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
Access-Control-Expose-Headers: Content-Type, Cache-Control, Expires, Etag, Last-Modified
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000
X-Endpoint: Travis::Api::App::Endpoint::Repos
X-Pattern: /:owner_name/:name
X-Oauth-Scopes: public
X-Accepted-Oauth-Scopes: public
Vary: Accept,Accept-Encoding
Cache-Control: no-cache
Etag: "a9e445ad2237440326816952c70dba79"
Pragma: no-cache
Expires: Mon, 28 Nov 2016 13:11:36 GMT
Content-Disposition: inline; filename="failing.svg"
Last-Modified: Thu, 24 Nov 2016 15:27:27 GMT
X-Content-Digest: 922c9cc746e8bc766b6acfed45d83e014df8a13e
Age: 0
X-Rack-Cache: miss, store
Via: 1.1 vegur
```

while this is from our badge:
```
$ curl https://zenodo.org/badge/6365411.svg -L -I                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
HTTP/1.1 302 FOUND
Server: nginx/1.10.2
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2016 13:06:05 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 279
Location: https://zenodo.org/badge/doi/10.5281/zenodo.178482.svg
X-Sentry-ID: None
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.10.2
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2016 13:06:05 GMT
Content-Type: image/svg+xml
Content-Length: 1189
X-Sentry-ID: None
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000
```

In our badge responses we should include headers such as ``Cache-Control``, ``Etag``, ``Pragma``, ``Expires``, ``Last-Modified`` so they are correctly not cached on GitHub. GitHub is hosting and caching the images on their side (probably copying our original header settings), hence the current badges will not be automatically refreshed if we start to cache information in new headers.

title: How to get a confirmed account with an invalid email address
body:
Not sure that's really an issue, but I've done this accidentally:
- Sign up with a valid address
- Don't click on the confirmation link yet
- After the sign up process you are already logged in: change your email address to a fake one
  (If the address was correct you would get a second email to confirm it)
- Click on the confirmation link of the first email

Your account is confirmed, with a fake email address.

title: setup: Docker recipe for Zenodo demosite on Linux
body:
## Description

Zenodo docker installation guide (http://zenodo.readthedocs.org/en/latest/installation.html#docker-installation) doesn't seem to work on Linux systems.

The `web` node in docker-compose fails with the following error:
`web_1      | pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: The 'zenodo' distribution was not found and is required by the application`

As far as I have gotten to finding the problem was to find out that the docker-compose `static` node doesn't mount the `./code` properly. Thus, all nodes that read the volumes from `static`, i.e. nodes `web`, `worker` and `frontend` will fail:

```
web:
  (...)
  volumes_from:
    - static
```

I was able to reproduce the problem on Ubuntu 15.04 and Archlinux (~03.2016) using newest `docker-machine` and `virtualbox` from package repositories.
## Tasks
- [ ] Fix the docker recipe so it works on Linux machine
- [ ] Confirm that it still works on OSX

IE9: PDF preview over HTTP
body:
In IE11 the following page doesn't load properly:
http://zenodo.org/record/15480/preview?filename=Cremops_wileycoytius_from_zt03916p083-2.pdf

while https version works:
https://zenodo.org/record/15480/preview?filename=Cremops_wileycoytius_from_zt03916p083-2.pdf

IE will load the page over HTTP and PDF.js will try to load the file over HTTPS, which seems to fail.

Safari/Chrome, on the other hand for some reason loads the preview page over HTTPS, and PDF.js still loads the file over HTTPS, which then works.

title: base: fix inveniogc
global: could not find any downloads that satisfy the requirement Invenio-Kwalitee
body:
When trying to `inveniomanage runserver` I get this error msg: 

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "/home/adrian/.virtualenvs/zenodo/bin/inveniomanage", line 5, in <module>
>     from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
>   File "/home/adrian/.virtualenvs/zenodo/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/**init**.py", line 3018, in <module>
>     working_set = WorkingSet._build_master()
>   File "/home/adrian/.virtualenvs/zenodo/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 614, in _build_master
>     return cls._build_from_requirements(__requires__)
>   File "/home/adrian/.virtualenvs/zenodo/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/**init**.py", line 627, in _build_from_requirements
>     dists = ws.resolve(reqs, Environment())
>   File "/home/adrian/.virtualenvs/zenodo/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 805, in resolve
>     raise DistributionNotFound(req)
> pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: pillow==2.0.0,>=2.4.0

As described [here](https://bitbucket.org/rptlab/reportlab/issue/55/setuptools-80-cannot-install-reportlab-318):

> Because of changes to how version specifiers are interpreted in PEP 440, setuptools 8.0 (released 13 Dec 2014) interprets these conditions with and instead of or, and since it's not possible to install a version that's both 2.0.0 and greater than 2.4.0, it's not possible to use setuptools to install reportlab from PyPI anymore. 

I think the solution here is to move to the newer version of `reportlab`, where they fixed the requirements.

body:
Reported by @LibrarPotter

Licensing Updates needed:
- Licenses to consider removing:
  - Apache Software License - Has been replaced with Apache License, 2.0 (which is also an option)
  - UK Click Use PSI - has been replaced with the UK Open Government Licence (OGL).
  - UK Crown Copyright with data.gov.uk rights - This does not appear to be a license option at this time. All information on data.gov.uk is currently covered under the Open Government Licence (OGL).
  - UK PSI Public Sector Information - This information is also entirely covered under Open Government Licence (OGL) now.
- Licenses to consider adding (found on http://creativecommons.org/choose/)
  - Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivatives 4.0 International
  - Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International
  - Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International

title: CC0 waiver in the T&C
installation: double requirements given in base/dev.requirements.txt
body:
**Invoking this** (zenodo/invenio:pu-zenodo | zenodo/zenodo:master):
`pip install -r requirements.txt --exists-action i`

**Produce this**:
`Double requirement given: ipython==2.3.0 (from -r dev.requirements.txt (line 26)) (already in ipython==2.3.0 (from -r base.requirements.txt (line 97)), name='ipython')
Storing debug log for failure in /home/adrian/.pip/pip.log
`
and
`Double requirement given: ipdb==0.8 (from -r dev.requirements.txt (line 26)) (already in ipdb==0.8 (from -r base.requirements.txt (line 96)), name='ipdb')
Storing debug log for failure in /home/adrian/.pip/pip.log
`

Shall we remove the `ipdb` and `iptyhon` requirements from `base.requirements.txt`?
